questions.text: What is the correct sequence of development of puberty in girls?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Sequence of puberty in girls.

  • G = accelerated growth or growth spurt (1st sign)
  • T = breast budding/Thelarche (1st visible sign of puberty)
  • P = Development of pubic hair-Pubarche
  • H = Increase in height/peak growth velocity attained
  • Menarche = Menstruation
  • On average, the entire time taken for puberty is 4.6 years.
  • Menarche occurs 2.6 years after the onset of puberty.

In males, the sequence of puberty

questions.text: Which of the following pubertal events in girls is not estrogen-dependent?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The main hormone responsible for secondary sexual characteristics in females is estrogen.
  • Estrogen leads to
    • Breast development
    • Growth spurt, i.e. height attained
    • Production of cervical mucus
    • Cornification of vaginal cells
    • Menstruation (menstruation occurs due to the withdrawal of progesterone in an oestrogen-primed uterus.)
  • As far as hair growth is concerned, in females also the hormone responsible is Androgens (produced by the adrenals and the ovary).

choices.text: Primitive gonads differentiate into testis due to the presence of the SRY gene
Androgen-binding protein is responsible for the development of male external genitalia

questions.text: During sexual differentiation in males, which of the following is true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The SRY gene (Sex-determining Region Y gene) located on the Y chromosome is essential for male sexual differentiation.
  • This gene triggers the transformation of the primitive gonads into testes, which then secrete:
    • Anti-Müllerian Hormone (AMH) from Sertoli cells- regression of Müllerian ducts.
    • Testosterone from Leydig cells- stabilisation and development of Wolffian ducts into male internal genitalia.
  • In males, masculinization of external genitals begins at 9-10 weeks and is completed by 12-14 weeks of gestation.
  • Thereafter, the only change is in the growth and length of the penis.
  • In males, mainly masculinization is due to testosterone/dihydrotestosterone; therefore, if it is deficient, it will lead to undermasculinization of the external genitalia, i.e. males will have a small phallus, hypospadias or scrotal defect, i.e. ambiguous genitalia.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Leydig cells produce Müllerian inhibiting substances (Option A): Müllerian inhibiting substance is produced by Sertoli cells, not Leydig cells.

Androgen binding protein is responsible (Option C): Development of male external genitalia is due to dihydrotestosterone (DHT), not androgen binding protein.

Wolffian duct regresses (Option D): In males, Müllerian ducts regress while Wolffian ducts develop.

questions.text: Which of the following forms the basis for sex chromatin testing?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The Barr body forms the basis for sex chromatin testing.
  • When two X chromosomes are present in a cell (as in a normal female), one of them becomes inactivated and condensed on the nuclear membrane and is called the 'Barr body'.
  • This process is termed X chromosome lionization (inactivation). The presence or absence of Barr bodies helps in ascertaining the sex of an individual.
  • Absence of Barr body indicates that the patient has only one X chromosome (eg. Normal male XY or Turner's syndrome (XO)
  • The nuclei of cells in females (XX) contain a darkly staining Barr body that is not present in the nuclei of cells in males.
  • Barr bodies are most easily seen in a smear of squamous epithelial cells obtained by scraping the buccal mucosa.
  • Barr bodies react differently to histological stains and are best seen as dark-staining bodies within the nucleus of non-dividing interphase cells.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Testosterone receptors (Option B): Not used for chromatin sex determination.

Hormone levels (Option C): Hormone levels do not reflect genetic sex.

Phenotypic features (Option D): Phenotype does not reliably indicate chromatin status.

questions.text: What is the treatment of choice for idiopathic central (true) precocious puberty?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • DOC for managing central precocious puberty is GnRH analogue(Leuprolide)
  • Principle:- Continuous administration of GnRH agonist downregulates and desensitises the GnRH receptor of the pituitary, decreasing gonadotropin release, leading to decreased estrogen production.
  • Note: In these females, GnRH should be withdrawn at the age of normal puberty.

Signs seen in precocious puberty include:

  • Early thelarche (breast development)
  • Early pubarche
  • Sometimes menarche (cyclical bleeding)

Explanation of other options:

Exogenous gonadotropins (Option A): Would worsen the condition by promoting further sexual maturation.

Ethinyl estradiol (Option B): Not indicated; estrogen would promote rather than suppress puberty.

Progesterone (Option D): Not effective in halting the hypothalamic-pituitary axis activation.

questions.text: Gynaecomastia is seen in all of the following conditions except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Gynecomastia is the benign proliferation of male breast glandular tissue due to an imbalance between estrogens and androgens, where estrogen predominance leads to glandular proliferation.
  • Prolactinoma, though it can cause galactorrhea and hypogonadism, does not cause true gynecomastia because prolactin does not directly stimulate breast tissue proliferation.

Causes include:

  • Estrogen excess: Gonadal tumours, hCG-secreting tumours, estrogen-secreting tumours. (Option B and C ruled out)
  • Thyroid dysfunction: Increased TSH leads to aromatase activity → raised estrogen. (Option B ruled out)

questions.text: A pregnant woman with a previous child affected by congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) asks about the best prenatal treatment to prevent genital virilisation in a potentially affected female fetus. Which of the following is the drug of choice?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (CAH) is a group of autosomal recessive disorders resulting from enzyme defects in cortisol biosynthesis, most commonly 21-hydroxylase deficiency.
  • The deficiency leads to excessive ACTH stimulation and increased androgen production, causing fetal virilisation in females.
  • In prenatal cases, the drug of choice (DOC) is Dexamethasone, administered to mothers at risk to suppress fetal adrenal androgen secretion.
  • Dexamethasone is preferred because it crosses the placenta and reaches the fetus to prevent virilisation of female external genitalia.
  • Postnatally, Hydrocortisone is used for long-term management, but it is ineffective prenatally as it does not cross the placenta.
  • Note: The Latest recommendations are prenatal treatment poses risks like postnatal failure to thrive and psychomotor developmental delay, hence the best approach is an early prenatal diagnosis by CVS with rapid sex determination (FISH for the X and Y chromosome) and genotyping and beginning treatment in only those mothers with an affected female child.

Explanation of other options:

Betamethasone (Option B): Used for fetal lung maturation, not for CAH prevention.

Prednisolone (Option C): Inactivated by placental enzymes, ineffective prenatally.

Hydrocortisone (Option D): Used for postnatal treatment, does not cross the placenta adequately.

questions.text: A newborn with 46XX has the external genitalia of a male. All the following are the possible causes except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The karyotype of the baby is 46 XX, and the external genitalia are male, i.e. it is a case of female pseudohermaphroditism.

Causes of female pseudohermaphroditism are:

  • Congenital adrenal hyperplasia. (M/C cause)
  • Increased androgens in the mother cross the placenta and cause virilisation of the external genitalia. Like maternal intake of androgenic drugs, maternal adrenal tumour, etc. (Option B ruled out)
  • Placental aromatase deficiency. The aromatase enzyme is responsible for the conversion of testosterone to estradiol. If this enzyme is deficient, there will be excess testosterone. (Option A ruled out)
  • Wnt4 mutation. WNT 4 Mullerian aplasia is a disorder that occurs in females and affects their reproductive system. There is abnormal development of the Müllerian duct and ovarian dysfunction, so females have an underdeveloped or absent uterus and may also have abnormalities of other reproductive organs. Women with this condition have primary amenorrhea, normal breast and pubic hair development and higher than normal levels of androgens in their blood. These high levels of androgens cause acne, hirsutism and virilisation. Kidney abnormalities may also be present in some affected individuals. (Option D ruled out)

AMH Deficiency/ Uterine Hernia Syndrome/Persistent Mullerian Duct Syndrome

  • It is seen in males
  • It is an autosomal recessive congenital disorder.
  • Karyotype = 46 XY
  • Gonads = testis
  • Hormone = Testosterone
  • Thus, external genitalia are normal since levels of testosterone are normal. The problem is that there is a persistent Mullerian duct, so the uterus and other Mullerian duct derivatives are seen in males.
  • Typical features: Include cryptorchidism and the presence of a small, underdeveloped uterus in a male infant or adult.
  • Here, since both the Mullerian duct and Wolffian duct are seen in males so the tissues are often intertwined, resulting in obstruction or non-patency of the vas deferens or other parts of the male excretory ducts. This can result in infertility.
  • The condition can come to attention because of a bulge in the inguinal canal of a male infant due to herniation of the uterus. There is no ambiguity or malformation of the external genitalia. They look like a normal male.

questions.text:
A 17-year-old phenotypic female is brought to the gynaecology OPD by her mother due to primary amenorrhea. She has well-developed breasts (Tanner stage V) but sparse pubic and axillary hair. On examination, her external genitalia appear female, but a blind-ending vagina is noted. Pelvic ultrasound reveals the absence of uterus and ovaries, and a shallow vaginal pouch. Her karyotype is 46, XY, and serum testosterone levels are within the normal adult male range.
Which of the following is/are features of this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This is a case of Complete Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome (CAIS), also known as Testicular Feminisation Syndrome.

In Testicular Feminisation Syndrome

  • Genotype- 46XY
  • Gonads- Testis (intrabdominal)
  • Phenotype- Female
  • Internal Genitalia- Is of males (except a short vagina may be present)
  • They are reared as females.

Lab investigation:

  • Testosterone levels may be normal/high/low depending on the degree of androgen resistance and the contribution of estradiol to feedback inhibition of the hypothalamus-pituitary axis.
  • Laboratory evaluation demonstrates elevated LH levels, normal or slightly elevated testosterone levels, and a 46 XY Karyotype.

Explanation of other options:

XX pattern (Option A): Karyotype is 46XY.

Commonly reared as male (Option B): They are reared as female due to external female appearance.

Well-formed female internal genitalia (Option C): No uterus, tubes, or upper vagina due to AMH action.

questions.text: A 15-year-old female presents with Primary Amenorrhea with a Short, Blind Vagina, with an absent Uterus. What Would be the next investigation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • A female presenting with primary amenorrhea, short blind vagina, and absent uterus raises suspicion of two primary differential diagnoses:
    1. Mullerian Agenesis (MRKH Syndrome)
    2. Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome (Testicular Feminisation Syndrome)
  • To differentiate between these two conditions, karyotyping is essential:
    1. Mullerian agenesis: 46, XX karyotype
    2. Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome: 46, X Y karyotype
  • Both conditions typically present with:
    1. Normal breast development
    2. Absence of uterus
    3. Short blind vaginal pouch
  • Key differentiating features:
    1. Axillary and pubic hair: Present in Mullerian agenesis; scanty or absent in Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome.
    2. Gonads: Ovaries in Mullerian agenesis; testes in Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome.

Explanation of other options:

IVP (Option B): Done to check associated renal anomalies in Mullerian agenesis but not first-line.

Gonadotropin levels (Option C): Not diagnostic in this setting.

Serum Prolactin (Option D): Not relevant to differentiate these conditions.

questions.text: A patient of 47 XXY karyotype presents with features of hypogonadism; the likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Klinefelter Syndrome

  • Genotype - 47 XXY
  • Klinefelter syndrome (KS) is the M/C cause of primary testicular failure, i.e. male hypogonadism affecting 1 in 1000 males.

Clinical features:

  • Small, firm testes (primary testicular failure)
  • Tall stature with long limbs
  • Gynecomastia (male breast development)
  • Decreased facial and body hair
  • Infertility due to azoospermia
  • Elevated gonadotropins (LH, FSH) with low testosterone

Explanation of other options:

Turner's syndrome (Option A): Occurs in females with a 45, XO karyotype. Presents with short stature, primary amenorrhea, and streak gonads.Not associated with 47, XXY or hypogonadism in males.

Edwards syndrome (Option C): Trisomy 18 (47, XX+18 or 47, XY+18).Presents with multiple congenital anomalies, intellectual disability, and early mortality.

Down syndrome (Option D): Trisomy 21 (47, XX+21 or 47, XY+21).Characterised by developmental delay, distinct facial features, and hypotonia.

questions.text: An 18-year-old patient came with primary amenorrhea. She had well-developed breasts and pubic hair. However, the vagina and uterus were absent. What would be your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Mullerian agenesis (also called Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser syndrome) is characterised by the congenital absence of the uterus and upper two-thirds of the vagina in females with normal secondary sexual characteristics.
  • Phenotype: Female
  • Genotype: 46, XX

Clinical Features:

  • Normal breast development
  • Normal pubic and axillary hair
  • Primary amenorrhea
  • Absent uterus and upper vagina (short blind vaginal pouch)

Ovarian function is normal, thus normal levels of estrogen, which explains normal breast development and secondary sexual characteristics.

Explanation of other options:

Turner syndrome (Option A): Genotype: 45, XO.Short stature, webbed neck, primary amenorrhea with streak gonads, lack of secondary sexual characteristics. The uterus is present but hypoplastic.

Klinefelter syndrome (47, XXY) (Option C): Occurs in males. Phenotypically male with small testes, tall stature, gynecomastia, and infertility.Does not present with absent uterus or vagina.

Gonadal agenesis (Option D): Characterised by the absence of functional gonads (streak gonads). Patients present with a lack of secondary sexual characteristics and the absence of a uterus.

questions.text: A 16 girl presents with primary amenorrhea with short stature and a widely spaced nipple. The Karyotype of the girl would be:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

TURNERS SYNDROME (also called as Gonadal Dysgenesis)

  • Karyotype: Most common = 45 XO
  • Gonads: B/L Streak Gonads. (since one single X chromosome is present ovaries are not properly formed).
  • Fallopian tubes, uterus and cervix and vagina developed from the Mullerian duct, these internal genitalia will present in the patient, but their proper growth requires oestrogen. So, they will remain infantile.

Explanation of other options:

46, XXY (Option B): Klinefelter's syndrome occurs in males.Features: Tall stature, gynecomastia, small testes, infertility

46, XY (Option C): Normal male genotype or could be seen in Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome if phenotypically female.

46, XX (Option D): Normal female genotype; would not explain primary amenorrhea with these features.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl with a height of 58 inches presents with primary amenorrhea and rising FSH. The histological findings most consistent with her conditions are:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • A height of 58 inches corresponds to approximately 147 cm. Which is short stature for a female of 16 years. Her FSH levels are rising, i.e., estrogen production is low, i.e. there is an ovarian cause for 1° amenorrhea.
  • Primary amenorrhea with short stature is seen in Turner's syndrome.
  • Turner syndrome (45 X) is the most common chromosomal abnormality causing gonadal failure; hence, on histological examination, the ovary should low oocyte count.
  • These patients present with short stature. (Height < 150 cms), primary amenorrhea and delayed secondary sexual characteristics.
  • They typically have many of the associated stigmata, including lymph oedema and sometimes large cystic hygromas of the neck, webbed neck, coarctation of the aorta, and horseshoe kidneys.

Explanation of other options:

Corpus luteum haemorrhage (Option B): Unrelated to primary amenorrhea; occurs in ovulatory cycles.

Marfan syndrome (Option C): Associated with tall stature, not short stature or amenorrhea.

Pituitary apoplexy (Option D): Presents acutely with headache, visual disturbances, and hormonal deficits, not with primary amenorrhea and short stature.

questions.text: A 16-year-old female with primary amenorrhea with her breasts at Tanner 4, but she has no axillary or pubic hair. The most likely diagnosis from below:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • When a female presents with a complaint of primary amenorrhea, the first thing to do is to examine her secondary sexual characteristics.
  • Androgen insensitivity syndrome/ Testicular feminisation syndrome is a form of male pseudo-hermaphroditism, gonadal sex is male with contrasting female phenotype.
  • It is the third most common cause of primary amenorrhea
  • In this condition, there is end organ insensitivity to androgen prevents masculinisation of internal and external
  • Genotype is 46 XY, The testosterone is converted to estrogen, hence they have well-developed breasts (Tanner stage 4 or 5), and since the development of pubic and axillary hair is dependent on testosterone, these are not developed or underdeveloped (Tanner stage 1 or 2)
  • In Turner's Syndrome, all secondary sexual characteristics are poorly developed, whereas in the question, the female has proper breast development with absent axillary and pubic hair (Option A ruled out).
  • In Mullerian agenesis: The patient presents with primary amenorrhea with well-developed secondary sexual characteristics (both breast and pubic hair), e. (Option B ruled out).
  • Premature ovarian failure: The patient will have no secondary sexual characteristics, be it breast or pubic hair. (Option D ruled out)

choices.text: One side steak and other dysgenetic gonads
One side streak and other normal looking gonad

questions.text: About Pure gonadal dysgenesis, what is true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Pure Gonadal Dysgenesis is characterised by bilateral streak gonads, which are underdeveloped gonads without hormonal or reproductive potential.
  • The internal genitalia (vagina, uterus, tubes) are present but may be infantile in size due to a lack of endogenous hormones.
  • The uterus is responsive to exogenous estrogen therapy.
  • The karyotype may be either 46, XX (Swyer syndrome) or 46, XY (Pure gonadal dysgenesis in males).
  • The phenotype is always female because of the absence of functioning gonads, irrespective of the chromosomal complement.

Mixed Gonadal dysgenesis:

  • In this disorder, the individual has a karyotype of 45XO/46XY, and so there is a streak gonad or no gonad on one side (corresponding to 45XO) and a testis on the other side (corresponding to 46XY).
  • Also known: Streak and dysgenetic gonads have a high potential for neoplasia (especially dysgerminoma or gonadoblastoma and Yolk sac tumour) if the owner's karyotype contains a Y chromosome.

Explanation of other options:

Bilateral dysgenetic gonads (Option B): This refers to Mixed Gonadal Dysgenesis, not pure gonadal dysgenesis.

One side streak and another dysgenetic gonad (Option C): Seen in asymmetric gonadal dysgenesis rather than the pure form.

One side streak and one normal-looking gonad (Option D): This pattern is seen in some cases of ovotesticular DSD (true hermaphroditism), not pure gonadal dysgenesis.

questions.text: A girl presents with primary amenorrhea with normal ovaries, absent internal genitalia, with normal external genitalia. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Mullerian agenesis or Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauserr syndromeis a congenital malformation characterised by a failure of the Mullerian ducts to develop, resulting in an absent uterus and variable malformations of the vagina, while both ovaries are intact and functioning.
  • Ovaries are present and function normally, so secondary sexual characteristics are normal. External genitalia are also normal as testosterone is absent.

The question says that the girl has normal ovaries, which rules out.

  • Turner's syndrome, where streak gonads are seen. (Option B ruled out).
  • Noonan's syndrome. (Option C ruled out).
  • Androgen insensitivity syndrome. (Option D ruled out)
  • Gonads are testes.

questions.text: Procedure of choice in case of uterine didelphys is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The procedure of choice for diagnosing uterine anomalies such as uterine didelphys is 3D transvaginal ultrasound (USG).
  • 3D USG is highly accurate, non-invasive, and can visualise both the external contour and the internal endometrial cavity, which is crucial for the diagnosis.
  • MRI is also highly accurate, but more expensive and less available than ultrasound.
  • HSG (Hysterosalpingography) may sometimes give false results due to poor visualisation of the external uterine contour. (Option C ruled out)
  • Laparoscopy + hysteroscopy is the gold standard for many uterine anomalies, but is invasive and not the initial choice. (Option A ruled out)
  • IVP(Intravenous Pyelogram) is used for urinary tract anomalies and has no role in the diagnosis of uterine anomalies. (Option B ruled out)
  • IOC for uterine anomalies = Laparoscopy + hysteroscopy > MRI > 3D USG

questions.text: Which is the most common congenital abnormality of the uterus among the given options?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The septate uterus is the most common congenital uterine anomaly, accounting for approximately 55-80% of all Müllerian anomalies.
  • It results from the failure of resorption of the midline septum after fusion of the Müllerian ducts.
  • It is often associated with recurrent miscarriage and infertility.

Explanation of other options:

Uterus didelphys (Option A) is a congenital anomaly resulting from the failure of fusion of the two Müllerian ducts. This leads to the formation of two separate uterine cavities, each with its own endometrial lining. It is less common compared to the septate uterus.

The arcuate uterus (Option B) is considered a mild anomaly characterised by a shallow indentation at the uterine fundus. It is typically asymptomatic and rarely associated with adverse reproductive outcomes.

Unicornuate uterus (Option C) is a rare congenital anomaly that arises due to incomplete development of one of the Müllerian ducts, leading to a single uterine horn. It is associated with poor obstetric outcomes but is much less common than a septate uterus.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presents with primary amenorrhea. On examination, she has normal secondary sexual characteristics, including well-developed breasts and pubic hair. Per vaginal examination reveals a blind-ending vagina. Imaging confirms an absent uterus. Which of the following features is not true about this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The most likely diagnosis is Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser (MRKH) syndrome.
  • It is a congenital condition resulting from the failure of the Müllerian ducts to develop properly, leading to an absent or hypoplastic uterus and the upper two-thirds of the vagina.
  • However, the ovaries are normal and functional, so ovulation occurs normally. Therefore, anovulation is not a feature of MRKH syndrome.
  • Patients typically present with primary amenorrhea in adolescence but have normal development of secondary sexual characteristics such as breasts and pubic hair due to normal ovarian estrogen production.

Explanation of other options:

Absent uterus(Option A): In MRKH syndrome, the uterus is absent or rudimentary due to Müllerian agenesis, which is a defining feature of the condition.

Absent vagina(Option B): The upper two-thirds of the vagina is either absent or underdeveloped in MRKH syndrome, leading to a blind-ending vaginal pouch.

46, XX(Option D): Patients with MRKH syndrome have a normal 46, XX female karyotype, which helps differentiate this condition from other causes of primary amenorrhea.

choices.text: Presence of rugosities of overlying vaginal mucosa

questions.text: Gartner's cyst can be differentiated from cystocele by all except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Gartner's cysts are cysts of the remnants of the Wolffian duct.
  • M/C location = Anterolateral aspect of the vagina, and hence are often confused with cystocele.
  • The presence of rugosities is not a feature of Gartner's cyst.

Features of Gartner's cyst are: The upper three-fifths above the hymen develop from the fused uterovaginal canal of the Müllerian ducts.

  • Rugosities of the overlying vaginal mucosa are lost.
  • The vaginal mucosa over it becomes tense and shiny.
  • Margins are well-defined.
  • Not reducible. (Option A)
  • No impulse to cough. (Option B)

questions.text: All of the following take part in male genital tract development except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • WNT-4 is an ovary-determining gene. This gene upregulates DAX1, which inhibits the expression of SOX9 in females.

Genes for male development:-

  • SRY gene-Master Gene for testis development (Option A)
  • SOX 9-SRY & SOX 9 induce the testis to form (Option B)
  • FGF-9 (chemotactic factor) FGF-9 causes tubules from the mesonephric duct to penetrate the gonadal ridge (Option C)
  • SF1 (steroidogenic factor)-It stimulates the differentiation of Sertoli or Leydig cells.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions are present with both Mullerian and Wolffian duct structures?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Anti-Mullerian hormone deficiency = persistent Mullerian duct syndrome = uterine hernia syndrome
  • The karyotype is 46 XY
  • Since the Y chromosome is present, gonads are testis, i.e. they are males. In this syndrome, in males, Sertoli cells fail to secrete Mullerian inhibiting substance, and the Mullerian duct is present.
  • Since Leydig cells are also present, they secrete testosterone normally, and the Wolffian duct is also present. So, in anti-Mullerian hormone deficiency, both Müllerian and Wolffian ducts are present.
  • Ovotestis: It is seen in true hermaphroditism. Both ovaries and testes are present. External genitalia are ambiguous. The internal structures depend on the degree of differentiation of the gonads. (Option C ruled out)
  • Mixed Gonadal dysgenesis Karyotype = 45XO/46XY. In this situation, the gonadal pattern on one side is a streak gonad ovary (corresponding to karyotype 45 XO) and a normal testis on the other side (corresponding to karyotype 46 XY)(Option D ruled out).
  • Mullerian duct and Wolffian duct development correlate with the character of the ipsilateral gonad.
  • Thus, both Mullerian duct and Wolffian ducts are present in AMH DEFICIENCY.
  • In the case of FSH receptor mutation in females, Mullerian ducts develop normally; the problem is in the binding of FSH to its receptors.
  • The patient presents with primary or early secondary amenorrhea, variable development of secondary sexual characteristics and high levels of FSH and LH.
  • Thus, only the Müllerian duct would be present as the karyotype of females is normal, i.e. 46(XX). (Option B ruled out).

questions.text: A girl with normal stature and minimal or absent pubertal development is seen in:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Kallmann syndrome is a form of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism characterised by normal stature with absent or delayed puberty due to deficient GnRH secretion from the hypothalamus.
  • Patients typically present with absent secondary sexual characteristics (breast development and pubic/axillary hair) and primary amenorrhea.
  • The stature remains normal, which is an important clue distinguishing it from other causes of pubertal failure.

Explanation of other options:

Turner syndrome (Option B): Turner syndrome (45, X) is associated with short stature along with primary amenorrhea and streak gonads. Normal stature in the question rules this out.

Testicular feminisation syndrome (Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome) (Option C: Here, breast development is present because peripheral conversion of androgens to estrogens occurs. However, pubic and axillary hair is absent. Thus, this is ruled out as the question mentions minimal or absent overall pubertal development.

Pure gonadal dysgenesis (Option D): Pure gonadal dysgenesis presents with absent secondary sexual characteristics but is often associated with tall or average stature and may also show features of gonadal failure. While close, Kallmann syndrome is more specific when both normal stature and minimal or absent pubertal development are considered.

questions.text: What is the most common gynaecological problem in prepubertal girls?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Vulvovaginitis occurs due to a lack of estrogen.
  • Most commonly seen in children.

Causes

  • Foreign body
  • Worm infestation
  • Tuberculosis
  • Infections such as candida

Symptoms are intense pruritus and offensive vaginal discharge.

Estrogen cream and treatment of infections are done for its management.

Explanation of other options:

Abdominal pain (Option A): Abdominal pain in children can have multiple causes, both gynaecological and non-gynaecological, but it is not the most common gynaecological complaint.

Vaginal spotting (Option C): Vaginal spotting is uncommon in prepubertal girls, as there is no cyclical endometrial activity before puberty.

Vaginal dryness (Option D): Vaginal dryness is typically associated with menopause rather than prepubertal girls.
